Author: seniorsassycat
Content:
"Ian's knot" has an extra twist that the square knot doesn't have, which avoids the common problem of tying a granny knot instead of a square when tying shoes.

A square knot is a left overhand knot tied on top of a right overhand knot, while Ian's knot is a double overhand knot tied on top of an overhand.

It looks like this knot could be called a surgeon's knot, although in that knot the double overhand knot is on the bitter end of the rope, while Ian's knot is the reverse.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surgeon%27s_knot"

Author: vezzy-fnord
Content:
In the latter case, unless you're black, you really don't know what you're talking about, and you had best shut up.

I'm Slavic. The very word "slave" originates from my ethnonym. I don't get offended by it, however.

Black people weren't the only ones who experienced slavery, I sincerely hope you know this. Even in the context of United States slavery, there were black slave owners. I disagree that one should "shut up" if they see an overreaction.

Author: nl
Content:
Yeah, I get that - and technically you are using a type 2 hypervisor (ie, non-bare metal[1]) so I guess the term is even kind of accurate.

Basically it will end up being exactly the same as Vagrant+Docker on a Mac, but without the Vagrant layer. That's really useful (and I'd love it on Windows too), but there's no need to try and invent a new term.

[1] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypervisor#Classification"

Author: perlpimp
Content:
My girlfriend gave me polaroid for the xmas. there has been a veil of nostalgia about whole digitization in making everything digital/internet - nothing stays around long enough to leave a lasting impression. while smartphone cameras are amazing there's nothing like black and white photo that you've made yourself in your bathroom/darkroom.

there is a great videoblog by Ted Forbes on youtube that covers this.

just sayin'

Author: nowarninglabel
Content:
"When I was in middle school, I went to a nerd summer camp called “Artificial Intelligence” in 1991 at Harding University. It was my first taste of programming. The language? LISP"

Yes! This was my experience as well! Though a couple years later. I've never read anything from someone else who went to the camp. One of the professors from back then is still there and the other professor is retired I believe, I e-mailed them last year sometime. That camp was so awesome! :)

Author: hga
Content:
When the employer mandate kicks in (it was illegally delayed a year), it's going to become increasingly difficult to suppress the knowledge that everyone subject to it is paying more while the big, self-insured---meaning they directly pay their employee's health costs, being big enough to not need an insurance company to make a big enough pool, only for claims processing services----aren't hardly so affected by it.

To pick so many people's favorite whipping boy, of course Wal-Mart was in favor of it. It's not going to see greatly increased costs , while it's Main Street competitors are going to get hammered.

Heck, they even escape 3 of the mandates; per the paper accessible at http://www.jdsupra.com/legalnews/affordable-care-acts-specia...

Out-of-Pocket Maximums – Ordinarily
Created: ACA requires group plans to limit out-of-pocket costs to $6
column14: ACA prohibits group plans with 100 or fewer employers and self-insured plans from medical underwriting and are exempt from the rating variation requirements based on age (3:1 ratio)
column18: ACA requires small group plans with 100 or fewer  employees to limit deductibles to $2
column20:
000 for family coverage.

If you think many big corporations are very evil
column21: you should be very concerned about the above."

Author: WalterBright
Content:
I've often tried hard to encourage friends, acquaintances, and family members to have an interest in programming. My success rate: 0%.

Similarly, a lot of people have bluntly told me I didn't have what it takes to write a compiler, run a business, invent a new programming language, etc.

I've concluded that I have no control over other peoples' thoughts and interests, and they have no control over mine.

Author: rayiner
Content:
Probably better as a 2034 resolution. I don't see the public's attitude towards the status quo changing substantially until the baby boomers, raised in the Cold War, start dying off. To them, the NSA helped Reagan,[1] destroy communism and win the Cold War. They're too young to remember the government's camp-down on progressives in the 1940's and 1950's, and so have personally suffered no negative consequences as a result of spying programs to date. I don't think their viewpoint is likely to budge, and the electorate's viewpoint in the aggregate will not budge until the boomers lose influence and representation.

[1] Ronald Reagan, no champion of civil liberties, had a staggering 74% approval rating as of 2010: http://www.gallup.com/poll/145064/kennedy-highest-rated-mode...."
